importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The incident occurred on Monday, October 19, 2025, at Hong Kong International Airport, marking a significant aviation safety event in the region.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The cargo plane skidded off the runway at approximately 3:50 a.m. local time, which is during early morning hours and a critical time for airport operations.

keyTakeAways: A cargo plane operated by ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport and crashed into the sea.
The aircraft broke in two upon impact, causing a collision with an airport security patrol car, resulting in the deaths of two staff members.
The four crew members on board were treated for injuries, with no cargo on board.
The incident occurred during a routine arrival from Dubai, and the aircraft did not send any distress signals.
The airport suspended operations on the north runway until the aircraft was removed from the sea, though operations on the other runways continued.
The flight was wet-leased from ACT Airlines, which operates as a cargo provider for major airlines such as Emirates.
Despite Hong Kong being one of the world’s busiest airports, fatal aviation accidents remain rare, though this incident underscores the risks of runway operations.
The event prompted a large emergency response involving over 200 people, fire engines, and boats.

namedEntities.name: Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major international airport located on an island west of Hong Kong's central district, one of the busiest in the world.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The airport is the location of the incident, where a cargo plane skidded off the runway and crashed into the sea, affecting airport operations and safety protocols.

namedEntities.name: Boeing aircraft
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A type of commercial aircraft manufactured by Boeing.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The aircraft type involved in the incident, which is part of the technical details of the crash and damage sustained.

namedEntities.name: ACT Airlines
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Turkish cargo carrier that operates cargo flights and provided the aircraft for this flight.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: ACT Airlines operated the cargo plane that crashed, and the flight was wet-leased from them, making them directly responsible for the aircraft's operation.

namedEntities.name: Emirates
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major international airline that assigned the flight number but did not operate the aircraft.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Emirates was listed as the flight operator by flight number, though the aircraft was wet-leased from ACT Airlines, highlighting the complexity of international cargo operations.

namedEntities.name: Steven Yiu
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Executive Director of Airport Operations at Hong Kong International Airport.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He confirmed the details of the incident, including the collision with a patrol car and the loss of life.

namedEntities.name: Wesley Yung
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Technical chief at Hong Kong’s Civil Aviation Department.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He confirmed that no distress signals were received from the pilots during approach, indicating the aircraft was under normal control until impact.

namedEntities.name: China Airlines
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major airline that experienced a major crash at the former Kai Tak Airport in 1999.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Historical context of aviation safety at Hong Kong airports, as a prior crash in 1999 involving China Airlines illustrates past risks at the region’s airports.

namedEntities.name: Kai Tak Airport
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The former airport in Kowloon City, known for being one of the world's most difficult airports to land at due to its location.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Historical context showing that prior to HKIA’s current site, aviation landings at Hong Kong were extremely challenging, offering context for current safety standards.

namedEntities.name: Patrol car
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An airport security vehicle present on the runway at the time of the incident.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was struck by the plane, leading to the deaths of two occupants and contributing to the severity of the incident.

namedEntities.name: Runway
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A section of the airport where aircraft take off and land.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The plane skidded off the runway, indicating a critical failure in landing procedures and a major safety issue at the airport.

namedEntities.name: Crew members
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The four individuals on board the aircraft who survived injuries.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Their survival and medical treatment highlight the outcome of the incident, contrasting with the fatalities of the two staff members.

namedEntities.name: Cargo
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The freight being transported by the aircraft.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article states there was no cargo on board, which may indicate the flight was a test or non-essential cargo mission.

namedEntities.name: Emergency response
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A large-scale response involving over 200 people, fire engines, and boats.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The scale of the emergency response underscores the severity of the crash and the logistical challenges of handling such an incident.

namedEntities.name: North runway
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: One of the runways at Hong Kong International Airport that was suspended after the incident.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The suspension of operations on the north runway reflects the immediate impact of the crash on airport infrastructure and flight operations.

namedEntities.name: Flight number Emirates
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The flight number assigned to the aircraft, though not operated by Emirates.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The flight number suggests the airline’s branding, even though the actual aircraft was operated by ACT Airlines.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A cargo plane operated by Turkish cargo carrier ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) during an arrival from Dubai, crashing into the sea and killing two airport staff who were in a patrol vehicle. The aircraft, a Boeing model, broke in two upon impact, with significant damage to the front section and tail. The four crew members on board were treated for injuries, and there was no cargo on board. The flight was wet-leased from ACT Airlines, though it carried an Emirates flight number. No distress signals were received from the pilots. The incident led to a massive emergency response involving over 200 personnel and the suspension of operations on the north runway. The event is notable given the airport’s history of rare but significant aviation accidents, including a 1999 crash at the former Kai Tak Airport, and highlights ongoing safety concerns despite Hong Kong’s status as one of the world’s busiest airports.
title: Two killed as cargo plane skids off runway into the sea in Hong Kong
